Republic of the Philippines 
 
A  loan  of  $500,000,000  is  proposed  to  support  the  Government’s 
countercyclical expenditure program. The loan is to be provided under 
the  Countercyclical  Support  Facility  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) as a single tranche.

The global crisis, which intensified after September 2008, has affected 
the  Philippine  economy  and  social  sectors  in  four  related  respects: 
(i) the first-round effects of the global financial crisis had repercussions 
for  the  domestic  financial  sector  in  the  second  half  of  2008;  (ii)  the 
second-round  effects  of  devastated  global  demand  has  hurt  the  real 
economy, sharply lowering its growth prospects for 2009; (iii) the impact 
on  fiscal  policy  has  resulted  in  declining  tax  revenue  collection  and  a 
larger  government  budget  deficit  than  initially  projected,  at  a  time  of 
limited access to global credit markets; and (iv) the economic and fiscal 
policy impacts threaten to undo recent gains in social policy spending, 
unemployment reduction, and poverty reduction programs.  

Given  the  second-round  effects  on  the  real  economy  and  emerging 
fiscal  constraint,  the  Government  of  the  Philippines  asked  ADB  to 
provide  a  countercyclical  support  loan  of  $500 million  to  support  its 
public  expenditure  program  for  2009.  The  Government  is  concerned 
about  its  ability  to  ensure  predictability  in  budget  financing  as  it  has 
already  provided  a  temporary  fiscal  stimulus  within  its  medium-term 
fiscal program. The Government projects gross financing requirements 
for 2009 at P451 billion in domestic financing and $4.3 billion in external 
financing,  including  domestic  and  external  debt  that  matures  in  2009. 
The  Government's  external  debt  amortization  profile  is  projected  to 
remain relatively high in 2010 with as much as $6.0 billion maturing in 
2010. Therefore, the countercyclical support loan will provide additional 
financing  to  the  Government  for  its  needed  larger  fiscal  stimulus.  This 
will allow the Government to stimulate an economic recovery, protect its 
social  spending  and  poverty  reduction  programs,  and  continue  with  its 
longer-term development objectives in 2009.   

The Government announced its countercyclical expenditure program in 
2009  and  integrated  it  into  the  2009  budget.  Since  the  national

The  proposed  loan  under  the  Countercyclical  Support  Facility  (CSF)  of  the  Asian

momentum  of  the  country’s  key  development  efforts  at  a  challenging  time  of  global  financial

related  respects:  (i)  the  first-round  effects  of  the  global  financial  crisis  impacted  the  domestic 
financial  sector  in  the  second  half  of  2008;  (ii) the  second-round  effects  of  reduced  global 
demand  have  hurt  the  real  economy  and  may  have  put  the  Philippines  in  an  economic 
recession  in  the  first  half  of  2009;  (iii)  the  impact  on  fiscal  policy  has  resulted  in  declining  tax 
revenue  and  a  larger  government  budget  deficit  than  initially  projected,  at  a  time  of  limited 
access to global credit markets; and (iv) the economic and fiscal policy impacts threaten to undo 
recent  gains  in  social  policy  spending,  unemployment  reduction,  and  poverty  reduction 
programs.  

3.

additional financing to the Government for the larger fiscal stimulus now needed.

THE GLOBAL CRISIS AND COUNTRY CONTEXT 

A. 

The Global Crisis and its Impact on the Philippine Economy, Employment, and 
Poverty 

9. 
The  global  financial  turmoil  has  impacted  developed  and  most  developing  economies, 
including the Philippines. The impact on developing countries has varied, but generally the crisis 
adversely impacted access to global financial markets; and resulted in a sharp downturn in the 
real  economy  with  ensuing  fiscal  stress,  and  higher  unemployment  and  poverty.  The 
International  Monetary  Fund  projects  the  global  economy  will  contract  this  year  and  only 
moderately  recover  next  year  as  financial  market  stabilization  will  take  longer  than  previously 
envisaged.  Developing  country  access  to  international  credit  will  remain  curtailed  as  a 
consequence.3  
 
10. 
Spillovers  from  the  global  financial  crisis  on  the  Philippine  domestic  financial  sector—
especially  banking—have  been  relatively  muted  because  of  limited  exposure  to  troubled  US 
assets, and low exposure to securitization and off-balance-sheet activities. The banking system 
remains sound with a capital adequacy ratio at 14% and gross nonperforming loans at 3.6% as 
of the end of May 2009. The equity market was impacted with equity prices falling by as much 
as 50% in 2008, in line with the experience of regional neighbors; it has since stabilized.  
 
11. 
However,  the  global  credit  crunch  that  emerged  in  September  2008  did  hurt  the 
Philippines by making access to international debt markets more expensive, for both the public 
and  private  sectors.  Yields  on  medium-term  domestic  bonds  increased  by  nearly  350  basis

B. 

The Government's Macroeconomic Management 

15. 
Appropriate and Responsive Policy. The Government's macroeconomic policy stance 
to the increased downside risks to the economy from the global crisis has been appropriate and 
responsive.  Several  key  macroeconomic  indicators  showed  improvement  in  2009  over  2008.  
On the external side, the current account is in surplus of about 4.9% of GDP for the first quarter 
of  2009.  Gross  international  reserves  continue  to  accumulate  and  reached  $39.5 billion  at  the 
end of May 2009, equivalent to 6.3 months of import cover and three times higher than external 
debt  maturing  this  year.  Conventionally,  at  least  3  months  of  import  coverage  is  considered  a 
sufficient buffer against modest shocks to the balance of payments. On the monetary side, the 
Central Bank of the Philippines (BSP) has operated an appropriate and timely monetary policy 
stance  throughout  the  crisis.  In  early  2008  it  raised  interest  rates  to  counter  the  threat  of 
second-round  inflationary  pressures  arising  from  the  surge  in  global  commodity  prices.  It  then 
shifted to an expansionary monetary position at the end of 2008 to provide sufficient liquidity to 
the banking system against the backdrop of rapidly falling inflation. The BSP currently maintains 
a neutral monetary stance. Inflation fell to 0.2% (year-on-year) in July 2009, well below BSP's 
inflation target range of 2.5%–4.5% for 2009. Inflation is expected to remain benign for the rest 
of this year, indicative of the slump in domestic economic activity.  
 
The  Government's  response  to  mitigating  the  risk  of  the  global  financial  crisis  on  the 
16. 
Philippine  financial  sector  involves  a  number  of  preemptive  measures  aimed  at  increasing 
liquidity in the domestic banking system, assuring confidence of depositors, and strengthening 
BSP's  lender  of  last  resort  facility.  These  measures  include  (i)  BSP  strengthened  its  lender  of 
last resort facility by increasing its budget for the peso rediscounting facility from P20 billion to 
P40  billion  on  14  November  2008,  and  opened  a  dollar  repo  facility  on  20  October  2008  to 
ensure  dollar  liquidity  with  the  banks’  dollar-denominated  Philippine  sovereign  bonds  as 
underlying  collateral;  (ii)  BSP  increased  liquidity  in  the  banking  system  by  easing  monetary 
policy  including  reducing  the  reserve  requirement  by  2 percentage  points,  (iii)  BSP  allowed 
financial institutions to temporarily reclassify their investments in debt and equity securities; and 
(iv)  Congress  approved  an  increase  in  the  ceiling  on  deposit  insurance  from  P250,000  to 
P500,000 per depositor to more closely align with recent adjustments in deposit guarantees in 
the  region;  With  these  preemptive  measures  in  place,  indicators  show  signs  of  improvement. 
Bank liquidity eased at the end of 2008 and bank lending continued robust growth at about 20% 
in  the  first  quarter  of  2009  on  a  year-on-year  basis;  the  stock  market  and  the  peso  have 
stabilized  since  November;  and  yields  on  short-  and  medium-term  (3 months  to  5  years) 
domestic  bonds  fell  back  to  precrisis  rates,  although  yields  on  longer-term  bonds  remain 
elevated. 
 
17. 
Public  Finances.  With the sharp contraction in global demand since September 2008, 
and the recognition by the Government and development partners that a larger fiscal expansion 
is  necessary,  the  Government  revised  its  fiscal  program  for  2009.  It  now  projects  a  national 
government  budget  deficit  of  3.2%  of  GDP  to  reflect  the  first  quarter  budget  outturn  and 
changes  in  the  budget's  macroeconomic  assumptions  (Table  2).  The  revised  budget  deficit 

 

 translates  to  an  actual  fiscal  expansion  of  up  to  2.3%  of  GDP  from  2008,6 low  by  regional 
standards.7 It  covers  about  40%–50%  of  the  expected  negative  output  gap  this  year  (i.e.,  the 
gap between potential and actual economic growth), suggesting that the expansion will have a 
moderate impact on mitigating the economic contraction (Appendix 6). 
 
18. 
The Government has announced its revised medium term goal of a balanced budget and 
decided it should be extended to 2013 instead of 2010 as originally planned, being aware of the 
need to provide investors with a sign of its commitment to maintaining a credible fiscal program 
with  clear  priorities.  It  targets  a  national  government  budget  deficit  of  2.5%  in  2010  (primarily 
achieved by cutting discretionary spending back to its medium-term spending targets), 1.5% in 
2011, and 0.5% in 2012; and a balanced budget by 2013. Recognizing its commitment to fiscal 
prudence  and  overall  sound  macroeconomic  management,  Moody's  upgraded  the  country’s 
sovereign credit rating from Ba3 to Ba1 with a stable outlook. The upgrade was prompted by the 
relatively high degree of resiliency in the banking system and the external balance-of-payments 
situation. The other two major rating agencies maintained the 2008 Philippines’ sovereign credit 
ratings of BB– stable (Standard & Poor’s) and BB stable (Fitch).  
 
19. 
The  medium-term  fiscal  targets  are  realistic  and  achievable,  but  will  require  increased 
effort to increase revenues by about 1 percentage point of GDP from 2010 to 2012. While the 
decline  in  tax  collection  is  substantially  attributable  to  the  economic  contraction  in  the  first 
quarter  of  2009,  weak  tax  administration  and  inefficiencies  in  tax  policy  have  also  resulted  in 
BIR being unable to increase value-added tax collections through improvements in tax efficiency 
and enforcement. Increasing tax revenue collection is a long-term challenge for the Government. 
Its  approach  is  threefold:  (i)  implement  tax  administration  reforms;  (ii)  enhance  and 
institutionalize  anticorruption  initiatives  in  BIR  and  BOC;  and  (iii)  improve  tax  policies.  Some 
progress  in  reforms  to  tax  administration  has  been  made  under  subprogram  3  of  the  DPSP, 
albeit  gradual  and  incremental.  BIR  has  prioritized  the  institutionalization  of  its  anticorruption 
revenue  program  (Run  After  Tax  Evaders  or  RATE).  Lessons  from  the  second  DPSP 
subprogram 8  indicate  that  these  initiatives  must  be  institutionalized  within  the  agencies  to 
ensure  they  are  sustainable,  permanent,  and  effective  deterrents  to  tax  evasion.  The 
Government  submitted  amendments  to  tax  legislation  (excise  tax  and  consolidation  of 
investment  tax  incentives)  to  enhance  tax  policy  efficiency  and  broaden  the  tax  base;  and 
proposed  simplifying  net  income  taxation  for  individuals  in  business.  Once  approved  by 
Congress, these legislative measures are estimated to increase tax collection by P35 billion in 
the first full year of operation.

IV. 

THE GOVERNMENT'S COUNTERCYCLICAL EXPENDITURE PROGRAM 

20. 
The  Government  announced  its  countercyclical  expenditure  program  in  2009  and 
integrated  it  into  the  2009  budget.  The  national  government  budget  does  not  have  automatic 
stabilizers embedded on the expenditure side of the budget. Therefore it had to announce the 
countercyclical expenditure program focusing on advancing infrastructure projects already in the 
investment  pipeline,  scaling  up  social  assistance  and  public  employment  programs,  and 
introducing policy measures to expedite budget disbursements. Overall, noninterest expenditure 
is  programmed  to  rise  by  20%  in  2009  over  2008,  providing  a  much-needed  boost  to  the 
economy. The 2009 national budget substantially increases spending on social sectors to help 
mitigate adverse impacts of the economic contraction on the poor. In real terms (i.e., inflation-
adjusted),  the  Department  of  Social  Welfare  and  Development's  budget  for  2009  has  doubled 
compared  with  the  2008  budget  (primarily  for  funding  the  conditional  cash  transfer  program); 
education  expenditure  has  increased  by  10%  and  health  spending  by  19%.  Overall,  spending 
on  social  sectors  increased  from  27%  of  the  budget  in  2005  to  31%  in  2009.  The  PHI-CS  in 
particular will support the Government's ongoing and scaled up social assistance programs and 
infrastructure  programs  in  the  social  sector  and  agriculture  included  in  the  2009  budget  and 
proposed 2010 budget (Table 3 and Development Policy letter in Appendix 1).

Social  Programs.  The  social  assistance  programs  are  implemented  within  the 
framework of the Government's national social welfare program. In February 2007, the National 
Economic and Development Authority passed a national definition of social protection and the 
types of programs covered by it. As the next step, the Government established an institutional 
framework  for  enhanced  delivery  of  social  protection  programs  that  specifically  assigns 
operating  responsibilities  of  the  National  Social  Welfare  Program  to  the  Department  of  Social 
Welfare  and  Development.  Within  this  context,  agencies  have  designed  or  refined  and 
implemented  several  social  assistance  programs  to  help  mitigate  the  worst  effects  of  the 
economic contraction on the poor. 
 
23. 
The Government has scaled up its social assistance and poverty reduction programs to 
protect  the  most  vulnerable  from  the  effects  of  the  economic  contraction.  These  programs 
include the hunger mitigation program, self-employment assistance kaunlaran (SEA-K) program, 
food  for  school  program,  family-based  conditional  cash  transfer  (CCT)  program,  and  the  new 
crisis-related comprehensive livelihood and emergency employment program (CLEEP), and the 
community-based  development  program  (Kalahi).  These  are  a  combination  of  short-term 
programs  to  mitigate  the  worst  effects  of  the  crisis  on  the  most  vulnerable  people  in  the 
community,  and  longer-term  programs  aimed  at  addressing  causes  of  poverty  such  as  limited 
access to education and health services for children (Table 3). Presidential Executive Order 782, 
issued in 2009, allocates 1.5% of ministries' maintenance expenditure to new hiring of displaced 
workers accredited with the Department of Labor and Employment on temporary contracts of up 
to 6 months. This could create an additional 40,000 jobs.

Economic  Stimulus  Effects.  The  national  government  budget  deficit  is  projected  at 
28. 
3.2% of GDP or an expansion of 2.4% over 2008 (deficit of 0.9% in 2008). An ADB assessment 
indicates that the stimulus effect of the expansion will be less than 2.4% of GDP as it depends 
on the type of spending activities in the stimulus package, and their multiplier effects and timing

29. 
Poverty  Impacts.  An  economic  slowdown  or  contraction  of  about  −0.5%  to  1.8%  in 
2009 will reduce per capita incomes ranging from –0.2% to –2.5%. This is expected to increase 
poverty in the short term because of the weak labor market and reduced household earnings. 
Over  the  medium  term,  a  slow  economic  recovery  will  create  persistently  high  unemployment 
and  suppressed  earnings  in  the  informal  sector  as  new  labor  market  entrants  outnumber  the 
new  jobs  created.  Structural  poverty  may  persist  as  poor  families'  access  to  social  services  is 
reduced.  The  Government's  fiscal  stimulus  will  partially  offset  the  unemployment  and  poverty 
impacts of the crisis; however, an economic recovery of about 5%–6% in 2011 is necessary to 
ensure  a  sustained  reduction  in  poverty.  The  CCT  and  employment  programs  (Table  3)  will 
have an immediate impact on the welfare of families, and are reaching a significant number of 
people likely to be affected by the crisis (Appendix 6). However, some of these programs (such 
as the subsidized rice program) are not well targeted; this will undermine their effectiveness.

SUMMARY OF DEBT SUSTAINABILITY ASSESSMENT 

 
1. 
The  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  undertook  an  Article  IV  Consultation  with  the 
Philippines  in  November  2008. 1  As  part  of  its  consultations,  the  IMF  undertook  a  debt 
sustainability  assessment  (DSA)  based  on  different  economic  growth,  interest  rate,  primary 
budget balance, and exchange rate shocks. The IMF updated its DSA for the purposes of the 
PHI-CS.  This  appendix  summarizes  the  pertinent  findings  of  the  DSA  as  well  as  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) assessment of the countercyclical expenditure program support loan 
using the IMF DSA as input.  
 
2. 
The  Philippines'  public  sector  debt  is  broadly  sustainable,  but  short-term  risks  have 
increased due to global financial instability. Public debt as a share of GDP has declined to ratios 
last  seen  in  the  early  1990s,  but  remains  high  by  regional  standards.  At  the  end  of  2008, 
national government public debt amounted to 56% of GDP, down from its peak of 83% in 2003 
(Figure A3). Nonfinancial public sector (NFPS) debt declined to 59.9% from 101.0% during the 
same  period  (Figure  A3).  A  prudent  borrowing  strategy,  including  lengthening  the  average 
maturity  of  debt  to  7.1  years  and  moving  to  domestic  financing;2 fiscal  discipline  (operating 
primary  budget  surpluses);  and  sustained  economic  growth  contributed  to  the  rapid  decline. 
Debt  servicing  costs  as  a  share  of  national  government  budget  revenues  also  declined  from 
36.7% in 2005 to 22.6% in 2007, thereby freeing up substantial resources for priority spending 
since 2007. However, at 8% of GDP, the Philippines’ public debt servicing costs (amortization 
and  interest  payments)  are  high  by  regional  standards.  The  debt  amortization  profile  is  lumpy 
with $8.4 billion in external public debt maturing in 2009 and 2010, increasing pressure on the 
Government’s gross financing needs (Figure A3).  
 
3. 
The  updated  IMF  DSA  indicates  that  public  sector  debt  is  broadly  sustainable.  In  the 
baseline  scenario,  no  new  fiscal  measures  are  introduced  over  the  medium  term  apart  from 
planned  reduction  of  the  corporate  income  tax  rate  in  2009.  In  this  scenario,  the  nonfinancial 
sector  public  debt  initially  rises  to  about  65%  in  2009/2010  and  then  declines  back  to  60%  of 
GDP  in  2014.  While  debt  dynamics  are  favorable  overall,  they  remain  vulnerable  to  shocks, 
especially exchange rate fluctuations, as 40% of public debt is external. For example, the IMF 
simulated a one-time permanent real depreciation of 30%, which led to a 20 percentage point 
increase in the external debt ratio from 2009, which would remain close to 80% in the medium 
term. The assessment also notes rising resilience to interest rate and growth shocks. Given the 
lengthening  of  maturities  and  increasing  utilization  of  domestic  financing,  external  debt  is  less 
affected  by world  interest  rates  and  domestic  growth  shocks.  It  is  only moderately  affected  by 
noninterest shocks to the current account. The DSA also simulates the impact of lower primary 
budget surpluses on debt over the medium term. It assumes a reduction in the average surplus 
from  2.7%  of  GDP  to  1.3%.  Under  this  scenario,  the  NFPS  debt  would  be  64%  in  2014.  The 
various scenarios are summarized in Table A3, with the baseline NFPS debt at 60% of GDP by 
2014. 
 
4. 
Implications  of  the  Countercyclical  Support  Facility  Loan. The loan of $500 million 
has  a  term  of  5  years  with  a  3-year  grace  period.  Two  principal  repayments,  each  of  
$250 million, will be made in the fourth and fifth year, i.e., 2013 and 2014. The loan is equivalent 
to  0.3%  of  GDP,  suggesting  that  in  general  the  underlying  sustainability  scenarios  are  not 
significantly impacted by the loan.

A.    Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the Philippines. The Countercyclical Support (PHI-CS) loan 
provides financing support to the Government's countercyclical public expenditure program aimed at stimulating the economy, 
protecting spending in the social sectors, and scaling up flagship social assistance programs to protect vulnerable groups in 
the community from adverse impacts of the global financial crisis. The national government budget does not have automatic 
stabilizers  embedded  on  the  expenditure  side  of  the  budget.  Therefore  it  had  to  introduce  a  countercyclical  expenditure 
program  focusing  on  advancing  infrastructure  projects  already  in  the  investment  pipeline,  scaling  up  social  assistance  and 
public  employment  programs,  and  introducing  policy  measures  to  expedite  budget  disbursements.  Overall,  noninterest 
expenditure  is  programmed  to  rise  by  20%  in  2009  over  2008  providing  a  much-needed  boost  to  the  economy.  The  2009 
national budget substantially increases spending on the social sectors. The Department of Social Welfare and Development's 
budget has doubled in real terms (i.e., inflation-adjusted) compared with its 2008 budget (primarily for funding the conditional 
cash transfer program); education expenditure has increased by 10% in real terms; and health spending by 19% in real terms. 
Overall, spending on the social sectors has increased from 27% of the budget in 2005 to 31% in 2009.  
 
The  PHI-CS  loan  supplements  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  program  loans  to  the  Philippines  and  in  particular  the 
Development  Policy  Support  Program  (DPSP)  cluster.  The  DPSP  policy  areas  largely  correspond  with  those  of  the 
Government as spelled out in the Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan 2004–2010, which focuses on five core areas: 
(i)  economic  growth  and  job  creation,  (ii)  energy  dependency  and  power  reforms,  (iii)  social  justice  and  basic  needs,  (iv) 
education and youth opportunities, and (v) anticorruption measures and governance. The plan‘s mission is to “fight poverty by 
building prosperity for the greatest number of Filipino people.”  
 
The  Government  has  made  substantial  progress  in  addressing  fiscal  consolidation  and  in  2008  shifted  focus  to  ensuring 
sustainable fiscal policy by enhancing tax revenues over the longer term. This is necessary to increase social expenditures. 
However, the global financial crisis and second-round effect of devastated external demand has hurt the Philippine economy. 
Fiscal  pressures  come  from  two  sources:  (i)  increased  public  demand  for  additional  social  spending  to  mitigate  poverty 
impacts, and (ii) a decline in budget revenues in the first quarter of 2009. The challenge faced by the Government is to protect 
recent  gains  in  social  expenditures,  plus  provide  additional  assistance  through  its  social  programs  such  as  the  conditional 
cash  transfer  program;  provide  a  fiscal  stimulus  through  increased  infrastructure  spending;  and  ensure  medium-term  debt 
sustainability. Consequently, the national government budget deficit will rise to 3.2% of gross domestic product this year and 
2% in 2010. This protects critical public spending and ensures fiscal discipline.  
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
1.  Key Issues. The apparent recessionary conditions in the Philippine economy threaten to reverse recent gains in reducing 
unemployment, which steadily declined during the last 2 years. Most recently, unemployment increased from 7.3% to 7.6%.

poverty impacts, the Government piloted the CCT program with 337,345 families in 2008 and 2009, and is expected broaden

terms of keeping vulnerable families out of poverty during hard times such as now.
